item.title: REST Constraint #6: Code on Demand‚ÄîWhen, Why, and How to Use It - Chris Woody Woodruff
item.description: Of all the REST constraints, Code on Demand is the one that most developers either overlook or actively avoid. Unlike the other five constraints, it is the only optional one, meaning a RESTful system doesn‚Äôt have to use it. But when applied correctly, it can unlock powerful capabilities in web applications. Let‚Äôs explore what Code on Demand is, when it makes sense to use it, and why most REST APIs don‚Äôt rely on it.

item.title: Chaining sudo on SSH to run PostgreSQL queries and dumps remotely
item.description:
Photo by Kvistholt Photography on Unsplash
It is common to run some commands via the postgres account as it is the de facto PostgreSQL super user. This means that if you're running these commands remotely, you'll need to chain sudo:
ssh pg-host sudo -i sudo -u postgres ...

item.title: REST Constraint #5: Embracing Layers for Flexibility and Scale - Chris Woody Woodruff
item.description: Building a reliable, scalable web application is no easy feat. The internet is unpredictable, traffic surges happen, and security threats lurk around every corner. That‚Äôs why REST includes the Layered System constraint‚Äîa design principle that structures applications into multiple layers, each handling a specific role. Whether it‚Äôs distributing traffic, securing data, or managing services, layering helps RESTful systems stay resilient and adaptable.
